channel.description: Recent content in Drinks on Sidecar

item.title: Little Bit Bittah
item.description: 2 oz vodka½ oz Campari1½ oz grapefruit juice½ oz grenadinegrapefruit wedge Shake vodka, Campari, grapefruit juice, and grenadine. Strain into rocks glass over ice. Garnish with grapefruit wedge.

item.title: Gin and Tonic
item.description: A deceptively simple drink, these particular instructions are meant to minimize the amount of carbonation lost from the tonic water. Recipe by Dave Arnold. Traditionally made with a London dry gin, but I think it’s fantastic with genever-style gin. 1¾ oz gin3¼ oz tonic water¼ lime, wedge Pre-chill a rocks glass and gin in the freezer. Add the gin to the rocks glass. Gently pour in the tonic water.

item.title: GBC
item.description: A refreshing, summery drink. 1 oz gin½ oz lime juice¼ oz simple syrup3 basil leaves, sliced into strips4 cucumber slices1½ tonic water Middle basil leaves, three cucumber slices, and simple syrup in the base of a rocks glass. Add the gin and lime, and crushed ice. Top with tonic water. Garnish with slice of cucumber.

item.title: Margarita
item.description: If you’re feeling extra adventurous, muddle one or two slices of jalapeño in your shaker before adding the ingredients. 2 oz tequila¾ oz orange liqueur¾ oz lime juice¼ oz agave syrup1 pinch of salt Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice.

item.title: El Presidente
item.description: 1½ oz white rum¾ oz curaçao or orange liqueur¾ oz dry vermouthdash of grenadineorange twist Stir all liquids with ice. Strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with orange twist.

item.title: Tabs vs. Spaces
item.description: It’s a programmer joke. I’m a nerd. 2 oz tequila½ oz Green Chartreuse¾ oz lime juice½ oz simple syruppinch of salt Add everything to a cocktail shaker with ice. Shake. Strain into a coupe glass.

item.title: Bijou
item.description: 1 oz London dry gin1 oz Green Chartreuse1 oz sweet vermouthlemon twist Stir the liquids in a cocktail shaker with ice. Strain into a coupe glass. Express the oils from the lemon peel over the drink and add it to the glass.

item.title: Cherry on Top
item.description: 6 fresh cherries, pitted1½ oz vodka½ oz Luxardo Maraschino¾ oz lemon juice¼ oz simple syrup Muddle five cherries in the bottom of your cocktail shaker. Add the liquids and ice. Shake. Double strain into a Collins glass filled with ice. Set a cherry atop the ice as a garnish.

item.title: Bannon Tantrum
item.description: “The media should keep its mouth shut and just listen for awhile”—Steve Bannon throwing a tantrum on Jan 26, 2017 This must be made with Dry Fly brand vodka; It has an amazing wheat flavor and I created this recipe specifically to let it shine. 2 oz Dry Fly vodka½ oz meyer lemon juice½ oz simple syrup Add everything to a shaker with ice. Shake. Strain into a rocks glass over ice.

item.title: Indian Winter
item.description: This uses honey syrup infused with cardomom pods. 1½ oz vodka½ oz lemon juice½ oz honey cardamom syrup1 egg white2 drops Angostura bitters1 star anise Add vodka, lemon juice, syrup, and egg white to a shaker. Dry shake, then add ice and shake. Double-strain into a coupe glass. Add a couple drops of Angostura bitters on top of the foam (for aroma). Float the star anise atop the drink.

item.title: The Definitive Irish Coffee
item.description: This approach uses burnt sugar syrup instead of granulated sugar, so I take pains to warm it and the whiskey before mixing with the coffee to avoid a lukewarm drink. Technically, any Irish whiskey will work, but you really ought to use Tullamore Dew. 1 oz Irish whiskey¾ oz burnt sugar syrup3½ oz extra strong fresh-brewed coffee1 oz cream, whipped until thick and frothy but still pourable Brew your coffee with the normal amount of grounds but half the normal amount of water so it is extra strong.

item.title: Old Fashioned
item.description: Some people will argue an Old Fashioned must be made with a sugar cube. Those people haven’t tried it with burnt sugar syrup. 2 oz rye whiskey¾ oz burnt sugar syrup2 dashes Angostura bitters2 dashes orange bittersorange twist Add ice to a rocks glass. Add both bitters, then the whiskey and burnt sugar syrup. The syrup will sink to the bottom, so give it a quick stir to mix.

item.title: Bees Knees
item.description: 2 oz gin¾ oz lemon juice¾ oz honey syruplemon twist Add gin, lemon juice, and honey syrup to a cocktail shaker. Shake. Strain into coupe glass. Garnish with lemon twist.

item.title: Blanc-arita
item.description: 2 oz silver tequila½ oz blanc vermouth½ oz lime juice½ oz agave syrup1 dash orange bitters Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into rocks glass over fresh ice.

item.title: Blushing Betty
item.description: 1½ oz bourbon1 oz grapefruit juice½ oz simple syrupgrapefruit twist Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into rocks glass over fresh ice. Garnish with grapefruit twist.

item.title: Brandy Alexander
item.description: 2 oz Cognac or other brandy1 oz heavy cream½ oz demerara syrupfresh grated nutmeg Add brandy, cream, and demerara syrup to a cocktail shaker. Shake. Strain into coupe glass. Top with grated nutmeg.

item.title: Daiquiri
item.description: 2 oz white rum¾ oz lime juice¾ oz simple syrup Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice. Shake well and strain into a coupe glass.

item.title: Maple Leaf
item.description: The recipe where I found this drink said, “drink on a porch with an old dog.” It’s solid advice. 2 oz bourbon¾ oz real maple syrup¾ oz lemon juicecinnamon stick Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into rocks glass over crushed ice. Garnish with cinnamon stick.

item.title: Vigo
item.description: I didn’t invent this drink, but I did invent the name. 2 oz orange juice1 oz London dry gin1 oz blanc vermouth¼ oz honey syrup2 oz sparkling wine Add all ingredients except the sparkling wine to a cocktail shaker with plenty of ice. Shake then strain into a wine glass. Top with the sparkling wine. Be disappointed by Mimosas for the rest of your life.

item.title: Mimosa
item.description: If someone asks you for a Mimosa, make them a Vigo instead. You’re welcome.

item.title: Manhattan
item.description: 2 oz rye whiskey1 oz sweet vermouth2 dashes Angostura bitters Combine in a shaker with ice. Stir, then strain into a coupe glass. Garnish with a Maraschino cherry.

item.title: Martini
item.description: Everyone has an opinion about martinis. I’ll spare you mine, and just give you my recipe. Trust me. I often use a blanc vermouth instead of the traditional dry, but it’s delicious with either. Any type of gin works in a martini, but I prefer a sweeter style. 2¼ oz genever gin¾ oz dry vermouth Add to cocktail shaker with plenty of ice. Stir well, then strain into a martini glass.

item.title: Negroni
item.description: The Negroni is my favorite drink. It’s quite sweet, but also bitter and complex. I make mine with Tanquery gin and Cocchi di Torino vermouth. It can also be served on the rocks, but I prefer it neat. This drink is a great test of your stirring skills. It really falls flat if you don’t stir it properly. 1 oz Campari1 oz London dry gin1 oz sweet vermouthorange twist Add all liquids to a mixing glass along with plenty of ice.

item.title: French Kiss
item.description: As always, use only high quality vermouth that is fresh (less than three months old). 2 oz sweet vermouth2 oz dry vermouth Build in a rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist.

item.title: Sidecar
item.description: The simple syrup isn’t traditional, but that’s how I learned it, and I like the touch of additional sweetness. 2 oz Cognac¾ oz orange liqueur¾ oz lemon juice¼ oz simple syruporange twist, discarded Shake vigorously with ice. Strain into a coupe glass. Express the oils from an orange twist over the drink, then discard the peel.
